[[Category:1837 short stories]] [[Category:Animal tales]] [[Category:19th-century British children's literature]] [[Category:1830s children's books]] [[Category:English fairy tales]] [[Category:British fairy tales]] [[Category:English folklore]] [[Category:Fairy tales]] [[Category:Fictional bears]] [[Category:Robert Southey]] [[Category:Female characters in fairy tales]] [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 1837]] [[Category:Short stories adapted into plays]] [[Category:Short stories adapted into films]]

{{for|the history of club disc jockeys|History of DJing}} [[File:WMCA Good Guys 1964.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Disc jockeys at [[WMCA (AM)]] New York in 1964]]
The '''history of radio disc jockeys''' covers the time when gramophone records were first transmitted by experimental [[radio broadcasting|radio]] broadcasters to present day [[radio personality|radio personalities]] who host shows featuring a variety of recorded music.
For a number of decades beginning in the 1930s, the term "disc [[jockey]]", "DJ", "deejay", or "jock"<ref name="Keith2006">Michael C Keith. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=NwCjMvxTq80C&pg=PT52 The Radio Station: Broadcast, Satellite & Internet]''. Taylor & Francis; 13 December 2006. {{ISBN|978-1-136-02777-2}}. p. 52–.</ref> was exclusively used to describe on-air personalities who played selections of popular recorded music on radio broadcasting stations.<ref name="Field2010">{{cite book|author=Shelly Field|title=Career Opportunities in Radio|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=35rkaH3TQG8C&pg=PA2|date=21 April 2010|publisher=Infobase Publishing|isbn=978-1-4381-1084-4|pages=2–}}</ref><ref name="Inc.1961">{{cite magazine|last=Harris|first=Arthur S., Jr.|title=How To Become A Disc Jockey|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lZf6xR3bNTcC&pg=PA27|work=[[Boys' Life]]|date=November 1961|publisher=Boy Scouts of America, Inc.|pages=27–}}</ref>
The term "disc jockey" first appeared in print in a 1941 issue of [[Variety (magazine)|''Variety'' magazine]],<ref name="Fong-Torres2001">Ben Fong-Torres. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=8qreFRzhjyIC&pg=PA22 The Hits Just Keep on Coming: The History of Top 40 Radio]''. Backbeat; 2001. {{ISBN|978-0-87930-664-9}}. p. 22–.</ref><ref name="Fisher2009">Marc Fisher. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=wxSnv8ZQFBUC&pg=PA13 Something in the Air: Radio, Rock, and the Revolution That Shaped a Generation]''. Random House Publishing Group; 2 April 2009. {{ISBN|978-0-307-54709-5}}. p. 13–.</ref> although the origin of the term is generally attributed to American radio news commentator [[Walter Winchell]] who used it to describe radio presenter [[Martin Block]]'s practice of introducing phonograph recordings to create a "Make Believe Ballroom" experience for radio listeners. The term combined "disc", referring to phonograph disc records, and "jockey", denoting the DJs practice of riding the audio gain, or alternately, riding a song to success and popularity.<ref name="Shepherd2003">{{cite book|author=John Shepherd|title=Continuum Encyclopedia of Popular Music of the World: VolumeII: Performance and Production|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pJvzEzjahkQC&pg=PA187|date=8 July 2003|publisher=A&C Black|isbn=978-0-8264-6322-7|pages=187–}}</ref>
Culminating in the "golden age" of [[Top 40]] radio, from approximately 1955 to 1975, radio DJs established a style of fast talking [[patter]] to bookend three minute pop songs.<ref name="NYT1">{{cite web|last1=Weingarten|first1=Markk|title=Radio Patter From the Past: Vintage D.J.'s Rock On|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/05/09/technology/radio-patter-from-the-past-vintage-dj-s-rock-on.html|website=[[New York Times]]|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=2 January 2017}}</ref> Unlike the modern [[disc jockey|club DJ]] who mixes transitions between songs to create a continuous flow of music, radio DJs played individual [[songs]] or [[Album#Music track|music tracks]] while voicing announcements, introductions, comments, jokes, and commercials in between each song or short series of songs.<ref name="Higgins">{{cite web|last1=Higgins|first1=Terry|title=Club Features New Breed of Disc Jockey|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1368&dat=19840629&id=hoFQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=OhIEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5730,6226527&hl=en|website=Milwaukee Sentinel|publisher=Milwaukee Sentinel, June 29, 1984|accessdate=7 July 2016}}</ref>
During the 1950s, 60s and 70s, radio DJs exerted considerable influence on popular music, especially during the [[Top 40 radio]] era, because of their ability to introduce new music to the radio audience and promote or control which songs would be given airplay.<ref name="NYTBooks" /><ref name="Battaglio">{{cite web|last1=Battaglio|first1=Stephen|title=Television/Radio; When AM Ruled Music, and WABC Was King|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/03/10/arts/television-radio-when-am-ruled-music-and-wabc-was-king.html?pagewanted=all|website=New York Times|publisher=New York Times Company|accessdate=8 July 2016}}</ref>
== 1900s to 1950s == [[File:1916 Lee DeForest Columbia broadcast at 2XG.JPG|thumb|right|150px|[[Lee DeForest]] broadcasting Columbia phonograph records on New York station [[2XG]] in 1916.]] In 1892, [[Emile Berliner]] began commercial production of his [[gramophone record]]s, the first disc records to be offered to the public. The earliest broadcasts of recorded music were made by radio engineers and experimenters. On Christmas Eve 1906, American [[Reginald A. Fessenden]] broadcast both live and recorded music from Brant Rock, Massachusetts. In 1907, American inventor Lee DeForest broadcast a recording of the [[William Tell Overture]] from his laboratory in the Parker Building in New York City, claiming "Of course, there weren't many receivers in those days, but I was the first disc jockey".<ref name="NYTBooks">{{cite web|last1=Udovitch|first1=Mim|title=Last Night a DJ Saved My Life The History of the Disc Jockey By BILL BREWSTER and FRANK BROUGHTON Grove Press|url=https://www.nytimes.com/books/first/b/brewster-dj.html|website=New York Times Book Review|publisher=New York Times Company|accessdate=8 July 2016}}</ref>
Ray Newby, of Stockton, California claimed on a 1965 episode of [[CBS]] ''[[I've Got a Secret]]'' to be regularly playing records on a small transmitter while a student at Herrold College of Engineering and Wireless in [[San Jose, California]] in 1909.<ref name="Secret">Ray Newby appearance on [[CBS]]' ''[[I've Got a Secret]]'', 27 September 1965. Secret listed as: "'I was the world's first radio disc jockey' (in 1909)." Rebroadcast on the [[Game Show Network]] on 22 May 2008.</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Bay Area Radio Museum|url=http://www.sfradiomuseum.com/schneider/radio113.shtml |title= Doc Herrold and Ray Newby |accessdate=21 May 2008}}</ref>
By 1910, radio broadcasters had started to use "live" orchestras as well as prerecorded sound. In the early radio age, content typically included comedy, drama, news, music, and sports reporting. Most radio stations had an orchestra or band on the payroll.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.americahurrah.com/NBC/RadioCity.htm |title=NBC's Radio City, San Francisco|author=Roddy, Bill|publisher=Roddy, Bill|accessdate=26 April 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.richsamuels.com/nbcmm/joeg.html |title=The NBC Chicago Orchestra|author=Samuels, Rich|publisher=Samuels, Rich|accessdate=26 April 2010}}</ref> The [[Federal Communications Commission]] also clearly favored live music, providing accelerated license approval to stations promising not to use any recordings for their first three years on the air.<ref name=Fisher/> Many noted recording artists tried to keep their recorded works off the air by having their records labeled as not being legal for airplay.<ref>{{cite news|title=Keep Your Big Mouth Shut ..Disc Jockeys Learn To Toil And Spin|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1310&dat=19550623&id=8w5WAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ZOIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4803,3719255|accessdate=29 December 2013|newspaper=Eugene Register-Guard|date=23 June 1955}}</ref> It took a Federal court ruling in 1940 to establish that a recording artist had no legal right to control the use of a record after it was sold.<ref name=Fisher/>
Elman B. Meyers started broadcasting a daily program in New York City in 1911 consisting mostly of recorded music. In 1914 his wife Sybil True broadcast records borrowed from a local music store. The first [[British people|British]] DJ was Christopher Stone, who in 1927 convinced the [[BBC]] to let him broadcast a program consisting of American and American-influenced jazz records interspersed with his [[ad lib]]bed introductions.<ref name=NYT />
One of the first women disc jockeys was Halloween Martin. She was on [[WBBM (AM)]] in Chicago as early as 1929, hosting a morning program she called the "Musical Clock." She played up-beat songs, gave the time and temperature, and read the latest weather.<ref>Jane Connolly. [https://www.depaulnewsline.com/archives/meet-depaul-legend-halloween-martin "Meet DePaul Legend Halloween Martin."] [[DePaul University]] Archives.</ref> Martin's [[morning drive|morning radio show]] format was uncommon in the late 1920s.<ref name="Keith2008">{{cite book|author=Michael C. Keith|title=Radio Cultures: The Sound Medium in American Life|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TXPG9-dA4BcC&pg=PA83|year=2008|publisher=Peter Lang|isbn=978-0-8204-8648-2|pages=83–}}</ref>
[[File:Martin_block_stan_kenton_wnewedited.jpg|thumb|upright|DJ Martin Block with [[Stan Kenton]].]] In 1935, American radio commentator [[Walter Winchell]] used the term "disc jockey" (the combination of ''disc'', referring to the disc records, and ''jockey'', which is an operator of a machine) as a description of radio announcer [[Martin Block]], the first announcer to become a star. While his audience was awaiting developments in the [[Lindbergh kidnapping]], Block played records and created the illusion that he was broadcasting from a ballroom, with the nation’s top dance bands performing live. The show, which he called ''Make Believe Ballroom'', was an instant hit.<ref name=Fisher>{{cite book | last = Fisher | first = Marc | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Something in the Air | publisher = Random House | date = | location = | pages = 11| url = | doi = | isbn = 978-0-375-50907-0 }}</ref>
Block was notable for his considerable influence on a records popularity. Block's program on station WNEW was highly successful, and Block was described as "the make-all, break-all of records. If he played something, it was a hit". Block later negotiated a multimillion-dollar contract with [[ABC Radio (United States)|ABC]] for a syndicated nationwide radio show.<ref name=NYT />
The earliest printed use of the term "disc jockey" appeared on August 13, 1941 when [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] published "... Gilbert is a disc jockey, who sings with his records." By the end of World War II, disc jockeys had established a reputation as "hitmakers", someone whose influence "could start an artist's career overnight".<ref name=NYT>{{cite web|last1=Brewster|first1=Bill|last2=Broughton|first2=Frank|title=Last Night a DJ Saved My Life - The History of the Disc Jockey|url=https://www.nytimes.com/books/first/b/brewster-dj.html|website=New York Times|publisher=The New York Times Company|accessdate=8 September 2015}}</ref>
Disputes with the [[American Society of Composers, Authors, and Publishers]] (ASCAP) and the [[American Federation of Musicians]] (AFM) affected radio DJs during World War II. ASCAP and AFM cited the decline in demand for live appearances of musical artists due to the proliferation of radio disc jockeys playing recorded music. The disputes were settled in 1944.<ref name="britannica.com">{{cite web|title=Disc jockey - Radio personality|url=https://www.britannica.com/art/disc-jockey|website=Encyclopædia Britannica|publisher=britannica.com|accessdate=6 July 2016}}</ref>
== 1950s to present == [[File:Dick clark radio show 1963.JPG|thumb|upright|[[Dick Clark]] in 1963]] The postwar period coincided with the rise of the radio disc jockey as a celebrity separate from the radio station, also known as a "radio personality". In the days before station-controlled playlists, the DJ often followed their personal tastes in music selection. DJs also played a role in exposing rock and roll artists to large, national audiences.
While at [[WJMO|WERE (1300 AM)]] in [[Cleveland]], [[Ohio]], DJ [[Bill Randle]] was one of the first to introduce [[Elvis Presley]] to radio audiences in the northeastern U.S.<ref name="Curtis">{{cite book|last=Curtis|first=James M. |title=Rock eras: interpretations of music and society, 1954-1984|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=F0xAUXaBYqoC&pg=PA42&dq=disc+jockey#v=onepage&q=disc%20jockey&f=false|year=1987|publisher=Popular Press|isbn=978-0-87972-369-9}}</ref> At [[WMCA (AM)]], DJ [[Jack Spector]] was the first New York City radio personality to play the new [[The Beatles|Beatles']] Capitol Records' single, "[[I Want to Hold Your Hand]]".<ref>{{cite book|last=Spizer|first=Bruce|title=The Beatles Are Coming!|year=2003|publisher=498 Publications|location=New Orleans|page=139}}</ref>
A top-rated radio host at [[WINS (AM)|WINS]] in New York City in the mid 1960s was Murray Kaufman, aka [[Murray the K]]. Kaufman took over the station's 7-11PM time period for several years. His show was known for its frenetic pace that incorporated segues, jingles, sound effects, and antics. After being invited by Beatles manager [[Brian Epstein]] to travel with the band, he came to be referred to as the "[[Fifth Beatle]]".<ref name="RHOF">{{cite web|title=Murray "The K" Kaufman|url=http://www.radiohof.org/murray_kaufman.htm|website=Radio Hall of Fame|publisher=National Radio Hall Of Fame}}</ref>
Notable [[United States|U.S.]] radio disc jockeys of the period include [[Alan Freed]], [[Wolfman Jack]], [[Casey Kasem]],<ref name="SissonZacher2007">{{cite book|author1=Richard Sisson|author2=Christian K. Zacher|author3=Andrew Robert Lee Cayton|title=The American Midwest: an interpretive encyclopedia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=n3Xn7jMx1RYC&pg=PA636|accessdate=13 October 2011|year=2007|publisher=Indiana University Press|isbn=978-0-253-34886-9|pages=636–}}</ref> and their [[England|British]] counterparts such as the [[BBC]]'s Brian Matthew and Alan Freeman, [[Wonderful Radio London|Radio London's]] [[John Peel]], [[Radio Caroline]]'s [[Tony Blackburn]], and [[Radio Luxembourg (English)|Radio Luxembourg]]'s [[Jimmy Savile]].<ref name="SterlingKeith2004">{{cite book|author1=Christopher H. Sterling|author2=Michael C. Keith|author3=Communications Museum of Broadcast|title=Encyclopedia of radio|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Z4XJQD4O_TkC&pg=PA375|accessdate=13 October 2011|year=2004|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-1-57958-249-4|pages=375–}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Big Day Belongs To The Local Hero|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2507&dat=19830912&id=iPU9AAAAIBAJ&sjid=CUkMAAAAIBAJ&pg=2175,2128192|accessdate=29 December 2013|newspaper=The Glasgow Herald|date=12 September 1983}}</ref>
[[File:AlanFreed-WinsNewYork-March231955.ogg|thumb|left|Radio DJ [[Alan Freed]] on New York City's [[WINS (AM)]] in 1955.]] Alan Freed is commonly referred to as the "father of rock and roll" due to his promotion of the music and his introduction of the term [[rock and roll]] on radio in the early 1950s. Freed also made a practice of presenting music by African-American artists rather than cover versions by white artists on his radio program. Freed's career ended when it was shown that he had accepted [[payola]], a practice that was highly controversial at the time, resulting in his being fired from his job at [[WABC (AM)|WABC]].<ref name="Altschuler2003">{{cite book|author=Glenn C. Altschuler|title=All shook up: how rock 'n' roll changed America|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lMyC2FndXwkC&pg=PA152|accessdate=13 October 2011|date=16 July 2003|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-513943-3|pages=152–}}</ref>
[[John R.]] (aka John Richbourg) listened to African-American DJ's on their programs talking the street patter and mimicked them. Richbourg's practice of using speech that simulated African-American street language of the mid-twentieth century led to [[WLAC]] programming an entire cohort of white DJ's that spoke like blacks did while playing music that was popular in the black community. This re-invigorated the station, and it stuck with not identifying the announcers until the mid-sixties. By then the rebellious youth market made the nightly rhythm and blues station the one they tuned to for rock and roll, as atmospherics carried the signal enabling the station to be heard throughout much of the [[North American]] continent and [[Caribbean]] islands.
[[File:Wolfman Jack in 1979.jpg|thumb|upright|Wolfman Jack]] Bob Smith (aka Wolfman Jack) began his career as an announcer on [[XERF]] located in Mexico and became an influential DJ who advocated for African American music on his long running rock and roll radio show. Many people thought Smith was a black DJ until he appeared as himself in the 1973 film [[American Graffiti]]. Smith hosted TV shows such as ''Midnight Special'' and ''Rock and Roll Palace''.<ref name="Komara2006">{{cite book|author=Edward Komara|title=Encyclopedia of the Blues|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-w-uGwm_LhcC&pg=PA1096|year=2006|publisher=Psychology Press|isbn=978-0-415-92699-7|pages=1096–}}</ref>
A number of actors and media personalities began their careers as traditional radio disc jockeys who played and introduced records, such as [[Hogan's Heroes]] star [[Bob Crane]], talk show host [[Art Bell]], ''[[American Idol]]'' host [[Ryan Seacrest]], and [[Howard Stern]].<ref name="Paxson2003">{{cite book|author=Peyton Paxson|title=Media Literacy: Thinking Critically about Music & Media|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ETz6OW44JQcC&pg=PA28|date=January 2003|publisher=Walch Publishing|isbn=978-0-8251-4487-5|pages=28–}}</ref> [[Dick Clark]] was a radio DJ at [[WFIL]] in [[Philadelphia]] before he began hosting [[WFIL-TV]]'s [[American Bandstand]].<ref name="Sagolla2011">Lisa Jo Sagolla. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=yRhBf_6L8B8C&pg=PA54 Rock 'n' Roll Dances of the 1950s]''. ABC-CLIO; 12 September 2011. {{ISBN|978-0-313-36557-7}}. p. 54–.</ref>
Radio DJs often acted as commercial brokers for their program and actively solicited paying sponsors. They could also negotiate which sponsors would appear on their program. Many wrote and delivered the commercials themselves, talking the place of advertising agencies who formerly executed these responsibilities.<ref name="Russo2010">{{cite book|author=Alexander Russo|title=Points on the Dial: Golden Age Radio beyond the Networks|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zBlyzQdnEssC&pg=PA165|date=20 January 2010|publisher=Duke University Press|isbn=0-8223-9112-0|pages=165–}}</ref>
[[Drive time]] or "morning drive" shows capitalized on a listening audience of weekday commuters and parents getting children ready for school. Morning DJs such as New York's [[Don Imus]] and DJ teams such as [[Mark and Brian]] in Los Angeles are examples of notable radio personalities whose morning drive format included playing songs as well as sharing stories and taking listener phone calls.<ref name="DelaneyMadigan2016">''[https://books.google.com/books?id=Dc2MDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA92 Lessons Learned from Popular Culture]''. SUNY Press; 28 June 2016. {{ISBN|978-1-4384-6147-2}}. p. 92–.</ref>
Radio disc jockey programs were often syndicated, at first with hourly musical programs with entertainers such as [[Dick Powell]] and [[Peggy Lee]] acting as radio DJs introducing music and providing continuity and commentary,<ref name="Blanchard2013">{{cite book|author=Margaret A. Blanchard|title=History of the Mass Media in the United States: An Encyclopedia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vupkAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA569|date=19 December 2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-135-91742-5|pages=569–}}</ref> and later with radio personalities such as [[Casey Kasem]] who hosted the first nationally syndicated [[Top 40]] countdown show.<ref name="Sterling2013">{{cite book|author=Christopher H. Sterling|title=Biographical Encyclopedia of American Radio|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mdQq-663faAC&pg=PA207|date=13 May 2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-136-99375-6|pages=207–}}</ref>
== Record hops == In the 1950s, radio disc jockeys from local and regional radio stations took advantage of their popularity and augmented their income by playing records and performing as [[master of ceremonies]] at teen dance parties called [[sock hop]]s or [[Sock hop|record hops]]. The term came about because these events were commonly held at [[high school]]s, often in the school [[gym]] or [[cafeteria]], and dancers were asked to remove their hard-soled shoes to protect the varnished floor of the gymnasium.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mAdUqLrKw4YC|publisher=Routledge|year=2006|page=1811|first=Eric|last=Partridge|title=The New Partridge Dictionary of Slang and Unconventional English|isbn=9780415259385}}</ref><ref name="wcrg">{{cite web|title=Throughout the 1950s and 60s WPOP disc jockeys were all over Central Connecticut emceeing various record hops|url=http://www.wdrcobg.com/wpop_hopjocks.html|website=WCRG/WPOP|publisher=Man From Mars Productions|accessdate=14 February 2018}}</ref>
Record hops became strongly associated with early [[rock and roll]]. "[[At the Hop]]", a 1957 hit song by [[Danny and the Juniors]], described the scene: "where the jockey is the smoothest, and the music is the coolest at the hop".<ref name="NiefMcBride2014">{{cite book|author1=Ron Nief|author2=Tom McBride|title=The Mindset List of the Obscure: 74 Famously Forgotten Icons from A to Z|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nVU8BAAAQBAJ&pg=PT199|date=2 September 2014|publisher=Sourcebooks|isbn=978-1-4022-9347-4|pages=199–}}</ref>
In addition to the DJ introducing and playing popular records, local bands and solo recording artists sometimes performed live at these events. Record hops were often sponsored by radio stations as a way to promote their disc jockeys, or by [[Record shop|record stores]] to promote the sale of records. They were also sponsored by school or church organizations who considered them "wholesome recreation" for teenagers.<ref name="Cole2009">{{cite book|author=Clay Cole|title=Sh-Boom!: The Explosion of Rock 'n' Roll (1953-1968)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kWoLGiW-wnAC&pg=PA16|date=1 October 2009|publisher=Morgan James Publishing|isbn=978-1-60037-768-6|pages=16–}}</ref> Admission was either free, or a small admission fee was charged.<ref name="Renzoni2017">{{cite book|author=Tony Renzoni|title=Connecticut Rock ‘n’ Roll: A History|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=G_QvDwAAQBAJ&pg=PA22|date=7 August 2017|publisher=Arcadia Publishing Incorporated|isbn=978-1-4396-6207-6|pages=22–}}</ref><ref name="Graebner2010">{{cite book|author=William Graebner|title=Coming Of Age In Buffalo: Youth and Authority in the Postwar Era|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=q844jkouAYUC&pg=PA39|date=25 September 2010|publisher=Temple University Press|isbn=978-1-4399-0475-6|pages=39–}}</ref>
During the 1950s, [[Cleveland]] radio DJ [[Bill Randle]] personalized his own style of record hops called "Randle Romps" which he used to gauge the reactions of teenagers to new records he wished to promote while on the air. Cleveland DJ [[Alan Freed]] is credited with breaking down racial barriers by playing and promoting African American music at record hops in the early 1950s and 60s.<ref name="Ennis1992">{{cite book|author=Philip H. Ennis|title=The Seventh Stream: The Emergence of Rocknroll in American Popular Music|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dwJ4pa36cYkC&pg=PA155|date=December 1992|publisher=Wesleyan University Press|isbn=978-0-8195-6257-9|pages=155–}}</ref><ref name="Wolff2006">{{cite book|author=Carlo Wolff|title=Cleveland Rock and Roll Memories: True and Tall Tales of the Glory Days, Told by Musicians, DJs, Promoters, and Fans Who Made the Scene in the '60s, '70s, and '80s|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9UgqW39abh8C&pg=PA6|year=2006|publisher=Gray & Company, Publishers|isbn=978-1-886228-99-3|pages=6–}}</ref> In 1957 alone, disc jockey and [[American Bandstand]] host [[Dick Clark]] made 157 appearances at dances and record hops.<ref name="Giordano2017">{{cite book|author=Ralph G. Giordano|title=Pop Goes the Decade: The Fifties|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=u_skDwAAQBAJ&pg=PR18|date=5 June 2017|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-1-4408-4472-0|pages=18–}}</ref> [[Detroit]] radio DJ [[Robin Seymour (DJ)|Robin Seymour]] is credited with influencing the success of [[The Supremes]] and [[The Four Tops]] by promoting their appearances at his record hops.<ref name="Castelnero2006">{{cite book|author=Gordon Castelnero|title=TV Land Detroit|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hM5GmVWOVyUC&pg=PA147|year=2006|publisher=University of Michigan Press|isbn=0-472-03124-4|pages=147–}}</ref>
The practice of dancing to recorded music at record hops hosted by radio DJs in the 1950s influenced the emergence of the [[discotheque]] and modern [[Disc jockey#Club DJs|club DJs]] who would later specialize in mixing a continuous flow of recorded music for live audiences.<ref name="ShepherdHorn2012">{{cite book|author1=John Shepherd|author2=David Horn|title=Continuum Encyclopedia of Popular Music of the World Volume 8: Genres: North America|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=__DTvryrBZkC&pg=PA180|date=8 March 2012|publisher=A&C Black|isbn=978-1-4411-4874-2|pages=180–}}</ref>
== Pirate radio DJs == [[File:ERosko.jpg|upright|thumb|right|Radio Caroline DJ Emperor Rosko]] During the 1960s, [[pirate radio]] stations proliferated off the coast of [[England]] in response to popular demand for new music not provided by traditional radio outlets such as the [[BBC]]. Up to 21 pirate stations were active at one time, including [[Radio Caroline]], [[Wonderful Radio London]] and [[Radio Atlanta]]. DJs such as [[John Peel]], [[Tony Blackburn]], [[Kenny Everett]], [[Tony Prince]], [[Emperor Rosko]] and [[Spangles Muldoon]] pioneered an innovative, American-influenced style of presentation, often programming their personal music choices rather than adhere to a strict playlist, thereby winning large audiences hungry for youth-oriented sounds and the latest musical trends. When the [[Marine, &c., Broadcasting (Offences) Act 1967|Marine, &c., Broadcasting (Offences) Act]] virtually ended pirate radio in 1967, many offshore pirate radio DJs moved to the relatively progressive land-based [[BBC radio 1]] which was established that same year as a response to the public's changing musical tastes.<ref name="Chignell2009">{{cite book|author=Hugh Chignell|title=Key Concepts in Radio Studies|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZU0oAwAAQBAJ&pg=PT146|date=5 March 2009|publisher=SAGE Publications|isbn=978-1-4739-0360-9|pages=146–}}</ref>
== Wartime radio DJs == [[File:Willis Conover 1969.jpg|thumb|upright|Willis Conover on the Voice of America in 1969]] During [[World War II]], disc jockey programs such as ''[[GI Jive]]'' were broadcast by the U.S. [[American Forces Network|Armed Forces Radio Service]] to troops. ''GI Jive'' initially featured one of a series of guest DJs for each broadcast who would introduce and play popular recordings of the day; some were civilian celebrities, while others were servicemen. In May 1943, however, the format settled on a single regular host DJ, Martha Wilkerson, who was known on the air as "GI Jill."<ref>''The Directory of the Armed Forces Radio Service Series''. Greenwood Press. {{ISBN|0-313-30812-8}}</ref><ref name="MackenzieHarry">Mackenzie, Harry (1999). ''The Directory of the Armed Forces Radio Service Series''. Greenwood Press. {{ISBN|0-313-30812-8}}</ref><ref name="BivinsTom">Bivins, Tom. ''World War II on the Radio''. J387:Communication History document. University of Oregon.</ref> [[Axis powers]] radio broadcasts aimed at Allied troops also adopted the disc jockey format, featuring personalities such as [[Tokyo Rose]] and [[Axis Sally]] who played popular American recorded songs interspersed with propaganda.
During the [[Vietnam War]], [[United States Air Force]] [[sergeant]] [[Adrian Cronauer]] was a notable Armed Forces Radio disc jockey whose experiences later inspired the 1987 film ''[[Good Morning, Vietnam]]'' starring [[Robin Williams]] as Cronauer.<ref name="urgentcomm">{{citation|url=http://urgentcomm.com/mag/radio_real_life_adrian/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120509103859/http://urgentcomm.com/mag/radio_real_life_adrian/ |date=March 1, 2005 |accessdate=2013-01-13 |archivedate=May 9, 2012 |author=Jim Barthold |publisher=Urgent Communications |title=The real life of Adrian Cronauer |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>[http://www.historynet.com/adrian-cronauer-air-force-radio-announcer-in-vietnam.htm Adrian Cronauer: Air Force Radio Announcer in Vietnam] at HistoryNet.com</ref>
[[Cold War]] radio DJ [[Willis Conover]]'s program on the [[Voice of America]] from 1955 through the mid-1990s featured [[jazz]] and other "prohibited" American music aimed at listeners in the [[Soviet Union]] and other Communist countries. Conover reportedly had "millions of devoted followers in Eastern Europe alone; his worldwide audience in his heyday has been estimated at up to 30 million people".<ref name="Freund">{{cite web|last1=Freund|first1=Charles Paul|title=The DJ Who Shook the Soviet Union With Jazz|url=http://www.newsweek.com/dj-who-shook-soviet-union-jazz-360935|website=Newsweek|publisher=[[Newsweek]]|accessdate=23 August 2016}}</ref>
== African American disc jockeys == [[File:2011-01-08 Downtown Memphis TN 36.jpg|thumb|upright|Plaque commemorating radio DJ Nat D. Williams in downtown [[Memphis, Tennessee]]]] [[African American]] radio DJs emerged in the mid 1930s and late 1940s, mostly in cities with large black populations such as New York, Chicago, Los Angeles and Detroit.
[[Jack L. Cooper]] was on the air 91⁄2 hours each week on Chicago's WCAP and is credited with being one of the first black radio announcers to broadcast gramophone records, including gospel music and jazz, using his own phonograph.<ref name=aaregistry>[http://www.aaregistry.org/historic_events/view/chicagos-radio-voice-jack-cooper "Chicago's Radio Voice, Jack Cooper", at ''African American Registry'']. Retrieved 20 May 2014</ref>
DJ [[Herb Kent (disc jockey)|Herb Kent]] began his career in 1944 playing classical records on Chicago's [[WBEZ]], then an FM broadcasting service for the [[Chicago Public Schools]]. During the 1950s, Kent worked at [[WGRB|WGES]] in Chicago and then at [[WBGX|WBEE]] where he coined the phrase "dusty records" or "dusties." He spent several years as one of the original DJs at [[WVON]], a "heritage" station to Chicago's black community.<ref name="KentSmallwood2009">{{cite book|author1=Herb Kent|author2=David Smallwood|title=The Cool Gent: The Nine Lives of Radio Legend Herb Kent|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=f92pJ3JhaJYC&pg=PA80|year=2009|publisher=Chicago Review Press|isbn=978-1-56976-254-7|pages=80–}}</ref>
[[File:Hal B. Jackson.jpg|thumb|upright|Hal Jackson]] In 1939, [[Hal Jackson]] was the first African American radio sportscaster at [[WLXE|WOOK]]-AM in [[Washington, DC]], and later hosted ''The House That Jack Built'', a DJ program of [[jazz]] and [[blues]].<ref>[http://www.radiohof.org/hal_jackson.htm Hal Jackson] National Radio Hall of Fame</ref> Jackson moved to New York City in 1954, and was the first radio personality to broadcast three daily shows on three different New York stations.<ref>[http://www.nhregister.com/news/article/New-York-black-radio-pioneer-Hal-Jackson-dies-11453182.php New York black radio-pioneer Hal Jackson dies] New Haven Register</ref> In 1990, Jackson was the first minority inducted into the [[NAB Broadcasting Hall of Fame|National Association of Broadcaster's Hall of Fame]].<ref>Watkins, Mel (May 2012) [https://www.nytimes.com/2012/05/25/nyregion/hal-jackson-pioneer-in-radio-and-racial-progress-dies-at-96.html?_r=0 Hal Jackson, 96, New York Broadcaster Who Broke Racial Barriers in Radio, Dies] New York Times</ref>
Other prominent black DJs included [[Al Benson]] on WGES, who was the first popular disc jockey to play urban blues and use "black street slang" in his broadcasts. Jesse "Spider" Burke hosted a popular show on KXLW in Saint Louis, Missouri. James Early was featured on [[WROX (AM)]] in Clarkesdale, Mississippi. Ramon Bruce became a prominent DJ at [[WHAT (AM)]] in Philadelphia. Some of these radio pioneers of the [[Black-appeal stations|Black-appeal radio]] period presaged the [[Top 40]], playing recordings that were targeted to the black youth and reflected jukebox selections that were popular.<ref>Barlow, William (1999) Voice Over: The Making of Black Radio- Philadelphia:Temple Univ press {{ISBN|1-56639-666-2}}, pg100</ref> Most major U.S. cities operated a full-time rhythm and blues radio station, and as African Americans traveled the country they would spread the word of their favorite radio personalities.<ref name="Sterling2004">{{cite book|author=Christopher H. Sterling|title=Encyclopedia of Radio 3-Volume Set|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-UeveLMilioC&pg=PA45|date=1 March 2004|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-135-45649-8|pages=45–}}</ref>
[[Nathanial Dowd Gaston Williams|Nat D. Williams]] was the first African American disc jockey on [[WDIA]] in Memphis with his popular ''Tan Town Jamboree'' show. African American radio DJs found it necessary to organize in order to gain opportunities in the radio industry, and in the 1950s [[Joseph Deighton Gibson Jr.|Jack Gibson]] of [[WERD]] formed the National Jazz, Rhythm and Blues Disc Jockey Association. The group's name was later changed to the National Association of Radio and Television Announcers. In 1960, radio station managers formed the Negro Radio Association to foster and develop programming and talent in the radio broadcasting industry.<ref name="Barlow1999">{{cite book|author=William Barlow|title=Voice Over: The Making of Black Radio|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gJuIHrKBONMC&pg=PA97|year=1999|publisher=Temple University Press|isbn=978-1-56639-667-7|pages=97–}}</ref><ref name="Sterling2004" />
==Women disc jockeys==
With exceptions such as Halloween Martin's work in 1929 at WBBM in Chicago,<ref name="Keith2008" /> the radio DJ profession in the U.S. was historically male-dominated. However beginning in the Top 40 era, female disc jockeys became more common. Judy Dibble on [[WDGY]] in Minneapolis started as "sidekick" to a male DJ in the mid 1960s and later went on to host her own DJ show.<ref name="Halper2015" />
[[Alison Steele]] began her career at [[WNEW-FM]] in the late 1960s. Responding to an ad for female disk jockeys, Steele auditioned with 800 other women and was chosen with three others to launch an "all woman" format. When WNEW abandoned this format in 1967 after an 18‐month trial, Steele was the only one asked to stay on.<ref name="NYT1971">{{cite web|title=In the World of Radio, She's a Rare Bird|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1971/12/09/archives/in-the-world-of-radio-shes-a-rare-bird.html?_r=0|website=New York Times|publisher=[[New York Times]]|accessdate=3 April 2017}}</ref> As a late night show host, Steele created an on-air persona, calling herself "The Nightbird". Her popularity grew, drawing an average nightly audience of 78,000. In 1976, Steele was the first woman chosen by [[Billboard magazine]] as "FM Personality of the Year", and she was instrumental in promoting performers such as the [[Moody Blues]]. She worked as an announcer for [[Search for Tomorrow]] and also as a producer at [[CNN]], returning to WNEW in 1984. In later years, she was known as "The Grand Dame of New York Night".<ref name="SterlingSteele">Christopher H. Sterling. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=mdQq-663faAC&pg=PA363 Biographical Encyclopedia of American Radio]''. Routledge; 13 May 2013. {{ISBN|978-1-136-99375-6}}. p. 363–.</ref>
Maxanne Sartori was the first female progressive rock DJ on [[KSWD (FM)|KOL-FM]] in Seattle and was subsequently hired in 1970 as an afternoon DJ for [[WBCN-FM]] in Boston. Sartori has been credited with influencing the success of artists such as [[Aerosmith]] and [[The Cars]].<ref name="Neer2001">{{cite book|author=Richard Neer|title=FM: The Rise and Fall of Rock Radio|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=24wr6CsDyC8C&pg=PT245|date=18 December 2001|publisher=Random House Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-679-46295-8|pages=245–}}</ref><ref name="Alan2013">{{cite book|author=Carter Alan|title=Radio Free Boston: The Rise and Fall of WBCN|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Yn8WCDOUQQ8C&pg=PA63|year=2013|publisher=UPNE|isbn=978-1-55553-729-6|pages=63–}}</ref>
In 1973, [[Yvonne Daniels]] was the first female DJ hired by [[WLS (AM)]] in Chicago. [[WEPN-FM|99X FM]], RKO radio group in New York hired Paulie Riccio in 1974. [[WABC (AM)]] in New York hired DJ Liz Kiley in 1979.<ref name="Halper2015">{{cite book|author=Donna Halper|title=Invisible Stars: A Social History of Women in American Broadcasting|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FkKhBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA260|date=11 February 2015|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-317-52018-4|pages=260–}}</ref><ref name="Sterling">{{cite book|author=Christopher H. Sterling|title=Biographical Encyclopedia of American Radio|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mdQq-663faAC&pg=PA134|date=13 May 2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-136-99375-6|pages=134–}}</ref><ref name="Kosut2012">{{cite book|author=Mary Kosut|title=Encyclopedia of Gender in Media|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=94_fCgAAQBAJ&pg=PT531|date=1 May 2012|publisher=SAGE Publications|isbn=978-1-5063-3828-6|pages=531–}}</ref>
Radio disc jockey [[Donna Halper]] is credited with discovering the rock band [[Rush (band)|Rush]] while working as a radio DJ at [[WMMS]] in Cleveland in 1974. After Halper played a track called “Working Man” on the air, listeners began requesting more Rush songs, prompting other radio stations to add Rush songs to their playlists. Acknowledging her role in their success, the band dedicated its first two albums to her.<ref>{{cite news | first = Vit | last = Wagner | title = What A Rush! | newspaper= [[Toronto Star]] | date = 2002-05-11 | page = J8}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last = McLean | first = Chuck | title = Quincy Woman Still Promoting Rush 34 Years After Discovering Band | newspaper= [[The Patriot Ledger]] | date = 2008-07-09 | url = http://www.patriotledger.com/entertainment/x2043505192/Quincy-woman-still-promoting-Rush-34-years-after-discovering-band}}</ref> Halper appeared in the documentary, ''[[Rush: Beyond the Lighted Stage]]'',<ref>[http://blogs.wickedlocal.com/whattodo/2010/06/10/women-see-underlying-theme-in-rush-documentary-film/ "Women see 'underlying theme' in Rush documentary film"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100619233846/http://blogs.wickedlocal.com/whattodo/2010/06/10/women-see-underlying-theme-in-rush-documentary-film/ |date=2010-06-19 }}</ref> and spoke at Rush's [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]] ceremony.<ref>[http://www.patriotledger.com/features/x41606795/Rush-gets-a-star-in-Hollywood-with-an-assist-from-Quincy-woman "Rush gets a star in Hollywood with an assist from Quincy woman"]</ref><ref name="Howl">{{cite web|last1=Tsui|first1=Nick|title=Legendary DJ Donna Halper was first to spin Rush in America|url=http://howlmag.com/odyssey-with-rush/|website=Howl Magazine|publisher=Howl Magazine|accessdate=22 January 2018}}</ref>
DJ Karen Begin (aka Darien O'Toole) is credited with being the first female [[shock jock]]. She promoted herself as the "Morning Beyotch" and "The Antidote to Howard Stern" on her show on San Francisco radio stations [[KSAN-FM|KSAN]] and [[KFRC-FM]] in the late 1990s.<ref>Justin Berton, [http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/Darian-O-Toole-S-F-disc-jockey-dies-at-40-3220623.php Darian O'Toole, S.F. disc jockey dies at 40] SFGate.com</ref>
"Less than a handful" of women were employed as radio DJs in [[United Kingdom|Britain]] before the 1970s. DJ [[Annie Nightingale]] hosted a progressive rock show on BBC Radio 1 in 1969. In 1998, Zoe Ball began hosting the BBC's key breakfast show slot, followed by Sarah Cox in 2000.<ref name="SterlingEncyclopedia">{{cite book|author=Christopher H. Sterling|title=Encyclopedia of Radio 3-Volume Set|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-UeveLMilioC&pg=PA377|date=1 March 2004|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-135-45649-8|pages=377–}}</ref>
== Payola scandal == {{main|Payola}} Especially during the 1950s, the sales success of any record depended to a large extent on its airplay by popular radio disc jockeys.<ref name="britannica.com" /> The [[Commercial bribery|illegal practice of payment]] or other inducement by record companies for the radio broadcast of recordings on [[music radio#Commercial radio|commercial radio]] in which the song is presented by a DJ as being part of the normal day's broadcast became known in the music industry as "payola". The first major [[United States Senate]] payola investigation occurred in 1959. Nationally renowned DJ Alan Freed, who was uncooperative in committee hearings, was fired as a result. DJ [[Dick Clark]] also testified before the committee, but survived, partially due to the fact that he had previously divested himself of ownership interest in all of his music-industry holdings.<ref>{{cite web|title=Dick Clark survives the Payola Scandal|url=http://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/dick-clark-survives-the-payola-scandal|work=history.com}}</ref>
After the initial investigation, radio DJs were stripped of the authority to make programming decisions, and payola became a misdemeanor offense. Programming decisions became the responsibility of station program directors. As a result, the process of persuading stations to play certain songs was simplified. Instead of reaching numerous DJs, record labels only had to connect with one station program director. Labels turned to independent promoters to circumvent allegations of payola.<ref>Cartwright, Robin (August 31, 2004). "[http://www.straightdope.com/mailbag/mpayola.html What's the story on the radio payola scandal of the 1950s?]." ''The Straight Dope.''</ref>
== Format changes == As radio stations moved from the AM Top 40 format to the FM [[album-oriented rock]] format or adopted more profitable programming such as news and call-in talk shows, the impact of the radio DJ on popular music was lessened. The emergence of [[shock jock]] personalities and [[morning zoo]] formats saw the DJs role change from music host to cultural provocateur and comedian.<ref name="Etling2011">{{cite book|author=Laurence Etling|title=Radio in the Movies: A History and Filmography, 1926-2010|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zsmP734Ka50C&pg=PA4|date=19 July 2011|publisher=McFarland|isbn=978-0-7864-8616-8|pages=4–}}</ref>
From the late 50s to the late 1980s when the Top 40 music radio format was popular, audience measuring tools such as [[Audience measurement#Diaries|ratings diaries]] were used. However a combination of financial pressures and new technology such as [[voice tracking]] and the [[Portable People Meter]] (PPM) began to have negative effects on the role of radio DJs beginning in the late 1990s, prompting one radio program manager to comment, "There was a time when the “top 40” format was ruled by legends such as Casey Kasem, or Wolfman Jack, and others who were known for both playing the hits and talking to you. Now with PPMs, it is all about the music, commercials and the format."<ref name="McKay">{{cite web|last1=McKay|first1=Jeff|title=The State of the Disc Jockey|url=http://www.radioinfo.com/2013/01/29/the-state-of-the-disc-jockey-part-2/|website=Radio Info|publisher=radioinfo.com|accessdate=7 July 2016}}</ref> Such format changes as well as the rise of new music distribution models such as [[MP3]] and [[online music store]]s led to the demise of radio DJs reputation as trendsetters and "hit makers" who wielded considerable influence over popular music.<ref name="NYTBooks" /><ref name="Battaglio" />
== In film == * ''[[The Fog]]'' - [[Adrienne Barbeau]] plays fictional small town radio DJ Stevie Wayne. * ''[[Private Parts (1997 film)|Private Parts]]'' - [[Howard Stern]] plays himself in a dramatized treatment of his career as a radio DJ. * ''[[American Hot Wax]]'' - [[Tim McIntire]] plays real-life radio DJ [[Alan Freed]]. * ''[[Pirate radio (film)|Pirate radio]]'' - Based on radio DJs of the real-life offshore pirate [[Radio Caroline]]. * ''[[Play Misty for Me]]'' - [[Clint Eastwood]] plays fictional radio DJ Dave Garver who is menaced by a stalker. * ''[[Good Morning, Vietnam]]'' - [[Robin Williams]] plays real-life Armed Forces Radio DJ [[Adrian Cronauer]]. * ''[[Talk to Me (2007 film)|Talk to Me]]'' - [[Don Cheadle]] plays real-life radio DJ [[Petey Greene]]. * ''[[Pontypool (film)|Pontypool]]'' - [[Stephen McHattie]] plays fictional radio DJ Grant Mazzy.
== See also == * [[Radio personality]] * [[Black-appeal stations]] * [[Archives of African American Music and Culture]]
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
[[Category:American radio DJs]] [[Category:Radio personalities| ]] [[Category:Telecommunications-related introductions in 1909]] [[Category:Broadcasting occupations]] [[Category:DJing| ]] [[Category:Media occupations]] [[Category:Occupations in music]] [[Category:Radio presenters| ]]

{{Infobox organization | name = International Academy of Aquatic Art (or IAAA) | logo = | vector_logo = | type = [[Culture|Cultural organisation]] | founded_date = 1955 | founder = Mary Derosier, Richard J. Dodson, Henry Gundling | location_city = | location_country = USA | location = | area_served = United States | origins = | key_people = | focus = Organization for the development of swimming as a performing art. | method = | revenue = | num_volunteers = | owner = | Non-profit_slogan = | homepage = [http://www.aquatic-art.org www.aquatic-art.org] | dissolved = | footnotes = }} The ''' International Academy of Aquatic Art ''' (or '''IAAA''') is a [[nonprofit organization]] for the development of [[Human swimming|swimming]] as a [[Performing arts|performing art]]. It is based in the United States.
==History== The IAAA was founded in 1955 by former [[Synchronized swimming|synchronized swimmers]] from the USA in order to develop swimming as artistic, creative and non-competitive activity.<ref>[http://www.aquatic-art.org/history.htm History ] on the official website of the IAAA</ref> The incorporators were: *'''Mary Derosier:''' former national chairman of the [[Amateur Athletic Union]], which was one of the first organizations who invented synchronized swimming competitions<ref>[http://www.usasynchro.org/About_Synchro/history.htm History] on the official website of USA Synchronized Swimming. 2010.</ref> *'''Richard J. Dodson:''' in 1951 publisher of the first magazine for synchronized swimming, the ''Synchronized Swimmer''<ref>[http://www.fina.org/content/development Development.] of different forms of artistic swimming on the official website of ''Federation Internationale de natation'' (FINA).</ref> *'''Henry Gundling:''' synchronized swimming coach, manager and husband of synchronized swimmer [[Beulah Gundling]]
The IAAA regularly organizes festivals throughout the United States and Canada presenting different swimming performances with [[Choreography|choreographies]] for soloists, duets and groups. The IAAA swimmers are called '''''aquatic artists'''''. The style of the performances, which are shown by women and men as well, is a mixture of synchronized swimming, water ballet, ornamental, rhythmic and scientific swimming. In most cases the swimmers use different forms of [[art music]] for the programs presented at the IAAA festivals. [[Bert Hubbard]], one of the first male synchronized swimmers from the USA, is a board member of the IAAA and documents its history and artistic activities.
==Gallery== <gallery> File:Gundling Beulah - Claire de Lune - 04 1981 - Midwest Aquatic Art Symposium at Riverside-Brookfield High School - Illinois - photo Cathy Goodwin.jpg|Beulah Gundling: ''Claire de Lune '' (1981) File:Gundling Beulah - Orientale - IAAA Festival 05 1975 - Calgary-Alberta-Canada - photo Cathy Goodwin.jpg|Beulah Gundling: ''Orientale '' (1975) File:Hubbard Bert - left - Joan Hinderstein middle - Richard Proctor right - in Othello 1960.jpeg|Bert Hubbard (left), Joan Hinderstein (middle) and Richard Proctor (right) in 1960 in Bert Hubbard’s own choreography “Othello” after Giuseppe Verdi’s opera File:Hubbard Bert right - Diane Tulley left - His and Her Limelights - IAAA festival 1997 - photo Walter Wengel.jpeg|Bert Hubbard and Diane Tulley in ''His and her Limelights'' at the IAAA festival 1997 File:Gundling Beulah right - Henry Gundling left - 05 1980 - 26th IAAA Festival at Samford University in Birmingham - Alabama - photo Cathy Goodwin.jpg|Beulah Gundling and her husband Henry Gundling (left) in 1980 File:IAAA - left to right Henry Gundling Peg Seller Marge Sharpe Beulah Gundling Kay Curtis Norma Prince Lee Vanderpool Vaughan Baird - 05 1979 at Maine South High School - Park Ridge - Illinois.jpg|Group photo of the IAAA in 1979, left to right: Henry Gundling, Peg Seller, Marge Sharpe, Beulah Gundling, Kay Curtis, Norma Prince, Lee Vanderpool, Vaughan Baird </gallery>
==Further reading== *Robert E. Kerper: ''Splash - Aquatic Shows from A to Z'' (published by Michael Zielinsky, 2002)<ref>[https://ishof.org/2009---robert-kerper.html ''2009 Buck Dawson Authors Award.''] Information about the book by R.E. Kerper on the official website of the [[International Swimming Hall of Fame]]. April 18, 2018.</ref> *Dawn Pawson Bean: Synchronized swimming - An American history. McFarland Company Inc. Publishers, Jefferson (North Carolina, USA), 2005.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=o-dD3p8eTYUC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Dawn+Pawson+Bean&source=bl&ots=Ttj5GNxN_S&sig=ZsQi5jWwnYqTAhLVD1R_Tj81Kkg&hl=de&sa=X&ei=Ad4eUIqaHovNsgbLwYHgCQ&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Dawn%20Pawson%20Bean&f=false E-Book on Google website.] Contains information about Bert Hubbard on page 51.</ref> *[[Johanna Beisteiner]]: ''Art music in figure skating, synchronized swimming and rhythmic gymnastics/Kunstmusik in Eiskunstlauf, Synchronschwimmen und rhythmischer Gymnastik''. PhD thesis, [[Vienna]] 2005, (German). Contains information about the International Academy of Aquatic Art (Chapter I/2: ''History of synchronized swimming'', pages 40–55).<ref>[http://data.onb.ac.at/rec/AC05031512 Article] on the dissertation in the online catalog of the Austrian National Library. (German and English)</ref>

page.title: Latter Day Saint views on Mary

revision.text:
[[File:Andrea della Robbia Devotional relief VA 7630-1861 img01.jpg|thumbnail|160px|[[Mary (mother of Jesus)|Mary]] with [[Jesus]]]] The [[Latter Day Saint movement]] teaches that [[Mary (mother of Jesus)|Mary]] was the mother of [[Jesus]], whose father was [[God the Father]]. Latter Day Saints affirm the [[virgin birth of Jesus]]<ref>{{citation |first= Eleanor |last= Colton |contribution-url= http://contentdm.lib.byu.edu/cdm/ref/collection/EoM/id/4311 |contribution= Virgin Birth |title= [[Encyclopedia of Mormonism]] |location= New York, NY |publisher= Macmillan Publishing Co. |year= 1992 |volume= 4 |page= 1510}}</ref> but reject the Roman Catholic traditions of the [[Immaculate Conception]], the [[perpetual virginity of Mary]], and her [[Assumption of Mary|assumption]]. They also believe that the [[brothers of Jesus]] were her and [[Saint Joseph|Joseph]]'s biological children.<ref name = EOM>{{citation |first= Camille |last= Fronk |contribution-url= http://contentdm.lib.byu.edu/cdm/ref/collection/EoM/id/3906 |contribution= Mary, Mother of Jesus |title= [[Encyclopedia of Mormonism]] |location= New York, NY |publisher= Macmillan Publishing Co. |year= 1992 |volume= 2 |pages= 863–64 }}</ref> Mary is not seen as an intercessor between humankind and Jesus, and Latter Day Saints do not pray to Mary.<ref name = EOM/> The [[Book of Mormon]], part of the [[Standard Works|Latter Day Saint canon of scripture]], refers to Mary by name in prophecies of her mission,<ref>{{lds|Mosiah|mosiah|3|8}}</ref> and describes her as "most beautiful and fair above all other virgins"<ref>{{lds|1 Nephi|1-ne|11|13|20}}</ref> and as a "precious and chosen vessel."<ref>{{lds|Alma|alma|7|10}}</ref>
In the first edition of the Book of Mormon (1830), Mary was referred to as "the mother of God, after the manner of the flesh,"<ref>{{citation |title= [[The Book of Mormon]] |location= Palmyra, NY |publisher= E.B. Grandin |year= 1830 |page= 25}}. [http://www.inephi.com/25.htm Online reprint] at ''inephi.com'' by John Hajicek.</ref> a reading that was changed by [[Joseph Smith]] to "the mother of the Son of God" in subsequent editions (1837–).<ref> {{lds|1 Nephi|1-ne|11|18}}</ref><ref>Latter Day Saint author [[Hugh Nibley]] has argued that the change was made to "avoid confusion, since during the theological controversies of the early Middle Ages the expression 'mother of God' took on a special connotation which it still has for many Christians". ({{citation |url= http://maxwellinstitute.byu.edu/publications/books/?bookid=74&chapid=909 |chapter= 'There Can Be No More Bible' |title= Since Cumorah |edition= 2nd |location= Salt Lake City, UT |publisher= [[Deseret Book]] and [[FARMS]] |year= 1988 |origyear= 1967 |page= 6 |isbn= 0-87579-139-5 |oclc= 17618853 }})</ref>
Latter Day Saints also believe that God the Father is the literal father of Jesus Christ,<ref>{{citation |chapter-url= http://www.lds.org/manual/gospel-principles/chapter-11-the-life-of-christ?lang=eng |chapter= Chapter 11: The Life of Christ |title= [[Gospel Principles]] |location= Salt Lake City, UT |publisher= LDS Church |year= 2009 |page= 52–53 }}</ref> although how Jesus' conception was accomplished has not been authoritatively established.<ref>{{citation |authorlink= Robert L. Millet |first= Robert L. |last= Millet |year= 2005 |title= A Different Jesus?: The Christ of the Latter-day Saints |publisher= [[William B. Eerdmans Publishing Company]] |isbn= 978-0-8028-2876-7 |oclc= 57211270 |page= 74}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
[[Category:Latter Day Saint movement and society|Mary]] [[Category:Mariology]] [[Category:Mormonism and women|Mary]] [[Category:Point of view]]

[[File:Fauske marble.jpg|thumb|upright|Marble from [[Fauske]] in [[Norway]].]] [[File:Carrara 7737.JPG|thumb|Blocks of [[Carrara marble]] in [[Italy]].]]
The following is a list of various types of '''[[marble]]''' according to location.
(NB: Marble-like stone which is not true marble according to geologists is included, but is indicated by ''[[italics]]'' and [[List of types of marble#Endnotes|an endnote]]).
==Africa==
===Egypt=== *Galala Marbletag{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} *Alabaster Marble{{citation needed|date=August 2015}}
===Ethiopia=== *Dalati marble which is found in Western Oromia, is white in color processed in Addis Ababa and used for decorating floors and walls.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}}
===Tunisia=== * ''[[Giallo antico]]'' — also known as Numidian marble (''marmor numidicum'' in Latin), was a yellow marble quarried in Roman times from the area of [[Chemtou]], ancient Simmithu
==Asia==
===India=== *[[Makrana Marble]] - White Marble also known as ''Sangemarmar''. Used in the Construction of the [[Taj Mahal]], India.
===Turkey=== * [[Marmara Island|Proconnesian marble]]
==Europe== [[File:Naxos Marble.JPG|thumb|Marble quarry in [[Naxos]], [[Greece]].]]
===Belgium=== * [[Noir Belge]] * [[Griotte]]
=== Czech Republic === [[File:Slivenec limestone, cz.jpg|thumb|A [[stoup]] from brown Slivenec marble in the church in [[Dobřichovice]]]] See webpage [http://dekoracni-kameny.geology.cz/index_cz.pl Dekorační kameny] etc. * [[Slivenec marble]] (slivenecký mramor), from [[Barrandien]], [[Slivenec]] and [[Radotín]] (Cikánka, Horní Kopanina, Na Špičce, Hvížďalka quarries), [[Prague]]: reddish, rose, brown, grey, spotted with veins. From old times quarried by the [[Knights of the Cross with the Red Star]] order which received the Slivenec village in 1253 from [[Wenceslaus I of Bohemia|Wenceslaus I Přemyslid]], the Bohemian king. In 1923, the order sold the quarries to a private company. * [[Karlík marble]] (karlický mramor) from [[Barrandien]], [[Karlík]], [[Prague-West District]]: black with gold-yellow-colour veins * Podol marble from [[Vápenný Podol]], [[Chrudim District]]: white, grey-white, rosy * Křtiny marble (křtinský mramor) from [[Křtiny (Blansko District)|Křtiny]], [[Blansko District]]: grey, rosy, reddish * Cetechovice marble (cetechovický mramor) from [[Cetechovice]], [[Kroměříž District]]: white * Český Šternberk marble (šternberský mramor) from [[Český Šternberk]], [[Benešov District]], white * Pernštejn marble (pernštejnský mramor) from [[Nedvědice]], [[Brno-Country District]], white * Nehodiv marble (nehodivský mramor) from [[Nehodiv]], [[Klatovy District]], grey * Lipová marble (lipovský mramor) from [[Horní Lipová]], [[Jeseník District]], dark and light-coloured * Sněžník marble (sněžníkovský mramor) from [[Horní Morava]], [[Ústí nad Orlicí District]], light-coloured * Supíkovice marble (supíkovický mramor) from [[Supíkovice]], [[Jeseník District]]
===France=== * [[Griotte]]
===Germany=== * [[Villmar|Lahn Marble]] * [[Wunsiedel Marble]]
===Greece=== * [[Cipollino marble]] * [[Hymettus|Hymettus Marble]] * [[Parian marble]] * [[Pentelic marble]] * [[Skyros marble]]
===Ireland===
* ''[[Connemara marble]]'' (Verd antique, serpentine marble){{ref label|specialnotes2|B|none}} * [[Kilkenny marble]]
===Italy=== * [[Botticino Marble]] * [[Carrara marble]] * [[Pavonazzo marble]] * Siena marble * [[Red Verona marble]] * [[Rosso di Levanto marble]] * [[Calacatta Marble]]
===Macedonia=== * [[Sivec]] (Bianco Sivec)
===Norway=== * [[Fauske marble]]
===Romania=== * [[Bucova marble]] * [[Rușchița marble]]
===Poland=== * [[Green Marianna marble]] and [[White Marianna marble]] from the [[Śnieżnik Mountains]],<ref>[http://www.historic-quarries.org/quarries/quarry/676] Retrieved 2015-08-29 (dead link)</ref>
===Portugal=== * [[Rosa aurora marble]]
===Russia=== * [[Ruskeala]]
===Spain=== * [[Crema Marfil]] * [[Macael marble]] * [[Nero_Marquina_marble|Nero Marquina]] * [[Al-Andalus Red]] * [[Dark Emperador]] * [[Costa Sol Bronze]] * [[San Cristobal Ivory Cream]]
===Sweden=== * [[Swedish green marble]] * [[Ekeberg marble]]
==North America== [[File:Tomb of the Unknown Soldier 8.jpg|thumb|The [[Tomb of the Unknowns|Tomb of the Unknown Soldier]] at [[Arlington National Cemetery]], [[Virginia]], USA, is made of [[Yule marble]].]]
===United States=== * [[Creole marble]] * [[Etowah marble]] * [[Georgia Marble Company|Murphy Marble]] * ''[[St. Genevieve marble]]''{{ref label|specialnotes5|E|none}} * [[Sylacauga marble]] * ''[[Tennessee marble]]''{{ref label|specialnotes6|F|none}} * [[Vermont Marble Museum|Vermont marble]] * [[Tuckahoe marble]] * [[Yule Marble]]
==Oceania==
===New Zealand=== *Takaka Marble{{citation needed|date=August 2015}}
==Endnotes== '''''These entries are actually "false" marble, near-marble, or marble mis-nomers:''''' {{ordered list|list_style_type=upper-alpha | {{note label|specialnotes1|A|none}}Geologists consider [[Ashford Black Marble]] to be a type of [[carboniferous limestone]]. | {{note label|specialnotes2|B|none}}Geologists consider [[Connemara marble]] to be a type of [[serpentinite]]. | {{note label|specialnotes3|C|none}}Geologists consider [[Purbeck Marble]] to be a type of [[limestone]]. | {{note label|specialnotes4|D|none}}Geologists consider [[Sussex Marble]] to be a type of limestone. | {{note label|specialnotes5|E|none}}Geologists consider [[St. Genevieve marble]] to be an [[Oolite|oolitic]] limestone. | {{note label|specialnotes6|F|none}}Geologists consider [[Tennessee marble]] to be a compressed limestone. }}
==See also== {{portal|Geology|Lists}} * [[List of types of limestone]] * [[List of sandstones]]
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{italic title}} [[File:Dancer sculpture by Degas at the Met.jpg|thumb|right|200px|A photograph of the sculpture]] '''''The Little Fourteen-Year-Old Dancer''''' (French: ''La Petite Danseuse de Quatorze Ans'') is a sculpture begun c. 1880 by [[Edgar Degas]] of a young student of the [[Paris Opera Ballet]] dance school, a Belgian named [[Marie van Goethem]].
==Description== The sculpture is one-third life size and was originally sculpted in wax, a somewhat unusual choice of medium for the time. It is dressed in a real [[bodice]], [[tutu (clothing)|tutu]] and [[ballet slippers]] and has a wig of real hair. All but a hair ribbon and the tutu are covered in wax. The 28 bronze repetitions that appear in museums and galleries around the world today were cast after Degas' death. The tutus worn by the bronzes vary from museum to museum.
The exact relationship between [[Marie van Goethem]] and Edgar Degas is a matter of debate. It was common in 1880 for the "Petits Rats" of the Paris Opera to seek protectors from among the wealthy visitors at the back door of the opera.
Realistic wax figures with real hair and real clothes had also been popular in religious, Folk, and fine arts for centuries before Degas created his ''Little Dancer''.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Degas Sculptures|last=Joseph Czestochowski and Anne Pingeot|first=|last2=Reff|first2=Theodore|publisher=Torch Press|year=2002|isbn=|location=Memphis|pages=52–3|chapter=To Make Sculpture Modern}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Degas and the Little Dancer|last=Kendall|first=Richard|publisher=Yale University Press|year=1998|isbn=|location=|pages=32}}</ref>
The arms are taut, and the legs and feet are placed in a ballet position akin to fourth position at rest, and there is tension in the pose, an image of a ballerina being put through her paces, not posing in an angelic way. Her face is – "contorted, people thought it was a deliberate image of ugliness, but you could also say it's the image of a sickly gawky adolesecent who is being made to do something she doesn't totally want to do."<ref>[[Tim Marlow]] on... Degas, Sickert & Toulouse-Lautrec' Channel 5 TV</ref>
==History== [[File:Edgar Degas La Petite Danseuse de Quatorze Ans cast in 1997.jpg|thumb|left|160px|Angle from "The Complete Sculptures of Edgar Degas" collection at [[M.T. Abraham Foundation]], cast in 1997. Note the varying tutu.]]When the ''La Petite Danseuse de Quatorze Ans'' was shown in Paris at the Sixth Impressionist Exhibition of 1881, it received mixed reviews. [[Joris-Karl Huysmans]] called it "the first truly modern attempt at sculpture I know." Certain critics were shocked by the piece, and the dancer was compared to a monkey and an [[Aztec]]. One critic, Paul Mantz, called her the "flower of precocious depravity," with a face "marked by the hateful promise of every vice" and "bearing the signs of a profoundly heinous character."<ref>{{cite news | date=2011-11-02 | url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1998-10-11/features/1998284216_1_classical-sculpture-original-sculpture-dancer | title=Degas's Little Dancer is still on the point of controversy}}</ref> Comparisons with older art were made, perhaps partly because it was exhibited in a glass case, like classical sculpture in the [[Louvre]], and was dressed in wig and clothes.
After Degas' death, his heirs (brother and sister's children<ref>{{cite news | date=2011-11-02 | url=http://www.nga.gov/content/ngaweb/Collection/highlights/highlight110292.html | title=National Gallery of Art}}</ref>) made the decision to have the bronze repetitions of ''Le Petite Danseuse'' and other wax and mixed-media sculptures cast. The casting took place at the Hébrard foundry in Paris from 1920 until 1936 when the Hébrard foundry went bankrupt and closed.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Degas Sculptures|last=Joseph Czestochowski and Anne Pingeot|first=|last2=Pingeot|first2=Anne|publisher=Torch Press|year=2002|isbn=|location=Memphis|pages=34|chapter=Degas and His Castings}}</ref> Thereafter, "Hébrard" Degas ''Little Dancer'' bronzes were cast at the Valsuani foundry in Paris until the mid-1970s.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Degas’ Little Dancer, Aged Fourteen: The earlier version that helped spark the birth of modern art|last=Hedberg|first=Gregory|publisher=Arnoldsche Fine Art Publishers|year=2016|isbn=|location=|pages=10, 19, 28 n. 6–7, 30 n. 44, 74, 99 n. 221, 272–281}}</ref> Sixty-nine of Degas' wax sculptures survived the casting process. One copy of ''Le Petite Danseuse'' is currently owned by the creator and owner of [[Auto Trader Group|Auto Trader]], [[John Madejski]]. He stated that he bought the sculpture by accident.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}} That copy was sold for £13,257,250 ($19,077,250) at [[Sotheby's]] on February, 3rd 2009.<ref>{{cite news | date=2009-02-04 | url=http://www.artvalue.com/sale--9928--Sotheby-s-London-New-Bond-Street-L09601-Impressionist-Modern.htm | title=Auction results}}</ref> Another Hébrard ''Little Dancer'' bronze failed to sell at a November 2011 auction at [[Christie's]].<ref>{{cite news | date=2011-11-02 | url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/g/a/2011/11/02/bloomberg_articlesLU0CEK07SXKX.DTL | title=Degas Ballerina Fails to Sell at Christie's as Markets Plummet}}</ref>
[[File:La_Petite_Danseuse_de_Quatorze_Ans_by_Edgard_Degas,_1881_-_Ny_Carlsberg_Glyptotek_-_Copenhagen_-_DSC09283.JPG|thumb|Cast of "Etude du nu pour la ''Petite danseuse de Quatorze ans''" by Degas exhibited in the Ny Carlsberg Glyptotek, Dantes Plads 7, Copenhagen, Denmark.]]
To construct the statue, Degas used pigmented beeswax, with a metal armature, rope, and paintbrushes covered by clay for structural support.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Edgar Degas Sculpture: The Collections of the National Gallery of Art, Systematic Catalogue|last=Suzanne G. Lindsay, Daphne S. Barbour, and Shelley G. Sturman|first=|publisher=National Gallery of Art|year=2010|isbn=|location=Washington, D.C.|pages=116–119}}</ref>
The ''Little Dancer'' wax sculpture we see today is a reworked version of the original sculpture that was shown in 1881. After seeing the wax sculpture in Degas’ living quarters in April 1903, the New York collector Louisine Havemeyer expressed interest in buying the wax. After proposing a bronze or cast wax of the sculpture, which Mrs. Havemeyer refused, Degas took his wax figure upstairs to his working studio and told Vollard he was reworking the sculpture for Havemeyer for 40,000 francs.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Private Collection of Edgar Degas|last=Ann Dumas, Colta Ives, Susan Alyson Stein, and Gary Tinterow|first=|last2=Tinterow|first2=Gary|publisher=The Metropolitan Museum of Art|year=1997|isbn=|location=New York|pages=101|chapter=Appendix: Mary Cassatt on the Degas Sales and the Casting of Sculpture}}</ref> Degas never sold the sculpture to Mrs. Havemeyer. After Degas died, it was found in a corner of his studio. Paul Lefond, Degas’ biographer, described the ''Little Dancer'' wax after Degas’ death as "nothing but a ruin;"<ref>{{Cite book|title=Degas, vol. II|last=Lafond|first=Paul|publisher=H. Floury|year=1918–19|isbn=|location=Paris|pages=66}}</ref> and Mary Cassatt telegraphed Mrs. Havemeyer "Statue Bad Condition."<ref>{{Cite book|title=Degas|last=Jean Sutherland Boggs, Douglas W. Druick, Henri Loyrette, Michael Pantazzi, and Gary Tinterow|first=|last2=Pantazzi|first2=Michael|publisher=The Metropolitan Museum of Art|year=1988|isbn=|location=New York|pages=352, n. 12|chapter=The Little Fourteen-Year-Old Dancer}}</ref> However, the wax sculpture we know today is not a ruin. It is Degas' reworked second version of his wax figure. At some point before Degas extensively reworked his sculpture, he allowed a plaster to be cast from the wax figure. This recently re-discovered plaster records the ''Little Dancer''’s original pose, bodice, and hairdo. The plaster is now in a private collection in the United States.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Degas’ Little Dancer, Aged Fourteen: The earlier version that helped spark the birth of modern art|last=Hedberg|first=Gregory|publisher=Arnoldsche|year=2016|isbn=|location=|pages=10–64}}</ref>
The original wax sculpture was acquired by [[Paul Mellon]] in 1956. Beginning in 1985, Mr and Mrs Mellon gave the [[National Gallery of Art]] 49 Degas waxes, 10 bronzes and 2 plasters, the largest group of original Degas sculptures. ''Little Dancer'' was among the bequests. In 1997, the Airaindor-Valsuani foundry in France began casting a limited edition of Degas bronzes from the pre-1903 ''Little Dancer'' plaster. One such ''Little Dancer'' bronze is owned by the [[M.T. Abraham Foundation]], which, at times, is lent to other institutions and museums including the State Hermitage Museum in Saint Petersburg, Russia.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Edgar Degas: Figures in Motion|last=Mikhail B. Piotrovsky, Amir Gross Kabiri, Geraldine Norman, Jon Whiteley, June Hargrove, and Dalit Lahav-Durst|first=|publisher=Petronius Publishing House, Ltd.|year=2013|isbn=|location=St. Petersburg|pages=65}}</ref> Like the various states of many of Degas' prints, the Valsuani bronzes record the first version of Degas' ''Little Dancer'', while the Hébrard casts record the second and final state of the sculpture.
==Cultural references== Art historian Richard Kendall published a scholarly account of the history of Degas's sculpture, ''Degas and the Little Dancer'', with contributions by Douglas Druick and Arthur Beale.<ref>{{cite book|first=Richard|last=Kendall|title=Degas and the Little Dancer|publisher=Yale university Press|year=1998|isbn=0-300-07497-2}}</ref> The [[BBC Two]] documentary ''[[The Private Life of a Masterpiece]]: Little Dancer Aged Fourteen'', produced in 2004, closely examines the sculpture, the model, the circumstances of her life, and the critical reaction to the work. [[Cathy Marie Buchanan]]'s novel, ''The Painted Girls'', presents a fictionalised account of the life of [[Marie van Goethem]], the model for the sculpture,<ref>{{cite news | date=2009-02-04 | url=http://www.cathymariebuchanan.com/books/the-painted-girls | title=The Painted Girls}}</ref> as does Carolyn Meyer's young adult novel ''Marie, Dancing''<ref>{{cite news | date=2009-02-04 | url=http://www.readcarolyn.com/marie__dancing_109898.htm | title=Marie, Dancing}}</ref> and Laurence Anholt's children's picture book ''Degas and the Little Dancer''.<ref>{{cite news | date= | url=http://barronseduc.com/0812065832.html | title=Degas and the Little Dancer}}</ref> In 2014, the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, D.C. premiered the stage musical, ''[[Little Dancer (musical)|Little Dancer]]'', inspired by the story of the young ballerina immortalized by Edgar Degas in his famous sculpture. On September 12, 2016, Dr. Gregory Hedberg presented a paper entitled "Unraveling the Mysteries of Degas’ ''Little Dancer, Aged Fourteen''," at the French Institute, Alliance Français, in New York City.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8pr3OYfY0zc&feature=youtu.be|title="Unraveling the Mysteries of Degas’ Little Dancer, Aged Fourteen"|last=Hedberg|first=Gregory|date=|website=YouTube|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
The piece inspired two of [[Damien Hirst]]'s works, ''Virgin Mother'' and ''[[Verity (sculpture)|Verity]]''.<ref name="Mail">{{cite web |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2218664/The-bump-beach-arrives-Damien-Hirst-s-65ft-statue-pregnant-woman-place-seaside-town.html |title=Thar she rises! Bump on the beach arrives as Damien Hirst’s 65ft statue of a pregnant woman is hoisted upright in Iflracombe. But awesome or an eyesore?|work=Daily Mail|date=16 October 2012|author=Bond, Anthony|accessdate=1 December 2014}}</ref>
The sculpture is prominently featured in the 1993 thriller ''[[Malice (film)|Malice]]''.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category|La Petite Danseuse de Quatorze Ans}} *[http://www.nga.gov/content/ngaweb/Collection/highlights/highlight110292.html ''Little Dancer Aged Fourteen''] sculpture at the [[National Gallery of Art]]. *[https://www.npr.org/player/v2/mediaPlayer.html?action=1&t=1&islist=false&id=356981074 "''Little Dancer'' Musical Imagines The Story Behind Degas' Mysterious Muse" NPR] *[http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/works-of-art/29.100.370 ''The Little Fourteen–Year–Old Dancer''] sculpture at the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]]. *[http://tate.org.uk/servlet/ViewWork?workid=3705&searchid=26825 ''Little Dancer Aged Fourteen''] in the Tate Collection, London *[http://www.scva.org.uk/collections/mustseeobjects/index.php?collection=1&collection_object=43 ''Little Dancer aged fourteen''] in the Robert and Lisa Sainsbury Collection. *[http://www.hayhill.com/docs/degas/degassc.htm ''The Little Dancer, Aged Fourteen''] at the Hay Hill Gallery in London. *[http://www.nga.gov/content/ngaweb/exhibitions/2014/degas-little-dancer.html Degas's ''Little Dancer''] at the [[National Gallery of Art]]. *[http://www.mtabraham.org The ''Little Dancer of Fourteen Years'' at the M.T. Abraham Foundation] *[http://libmma.contentdm.oclc.org/cdm/compoundobject/collection/p15324coll10/id/60673/rec/6 ''Degas: The Artist's Mind''], exhibition catalog from The Metropolitan Museum of Art fully available online as PDF, which contains material on ''Little Dancer of Fourteen Years'' (see index) *[https://www.kennedy-center.org/calendar/event/TPTSA] ''Little Dancer'', The John F.Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. *"[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8pr3OYfY0zc&feature=youtu.be Unraveling the Mysteries of Degas’ ''Little Dancer, Aged Fourteen" YouTube] *[https://www.check123.com/videos/913-little-dancer-aged-fourteen-degas ''Little Dancer Aged Fourteen (Degas)'' - 2 Minute Video] | Check123 - Video Encyclopedia
